title: Mass Balance ‚öñÔ∏è
ques: Set up a **mass balance** for a mixer with two inlet streams (100 kg/h and 50 kg/h) combining into one outlet.

answer.content:
**Conservation of Mass:**
$$\sum \dot{m}_{in} = \sum \dot{m}_{out} + Accumulation$$

**For steady-state mixer:**
$$\dot{m}_1 + \dot{m}_2 = \dot{m}_3$$
$$100 + 50 = \mathbf{150\ kg/h}$$

**Component balance (if 30% A in stream 1, 60% A in stream 2):**
$$0.30(100) + 0.60(50) = x_A(150)$$
$$30 + 30 = 60 = x_A(150)$$
$$x_A = \mathbf{40\%}$$

explanation: Mass (and energy, momentum) balances are fundamental to chemical engineering design.

title: Distillation üß™
ques: Explain how **distillation** separates mixtures based on volatility.

answer.content:
**Distillation Principle:**
Separation based on different boiling points

**Process:**
1. Heat liquid mixture
2. More volatile component evaporates first
3. Vapor rises, condenses
4. Collect condensate (distillate)

**Types:**
| Type | Use |
|------|-----|
| Simple | Large boiling point difference |
| Fractional | Similar boiling points |
| Vacuum | Heat-sensitive materials |
| Extractive | Azeotropes |

explanation: Common application: crude oil refining into gasoline, diesel, etc. McCabe-Thiele method designs columns.

title: Reaction Kinetics ‚ö°
ques: For a **first-order reaction** with k = 0.1 min‚Åª¬π, calculate time for 90% conversion.

answer.content:
**First-Order Rate Law:**
$$-\frac{dC_A}{dt} = kC_A$$

**Integrated Form:**
$$\ln\frac{C_{A0}}{C_A} = kt$$

**For 90% conversion:** C_A = 0.1 C_{A0}
$$\ln\frac{C_{A0}}{0.1C_{A0}} = 0.1t$$
$$\ln(10) = 0.1t$$
$$t = \frac{2.303}{0.1} = \mathbf{23\ min}$$

**Half-life:** t‚ÇÅ/‚ÇÇ = ln(2)/k = 6.93 min

explanation: Order of reaction determines how rate depends on concentration. Determined experimentally.

title: Heat Exchangers üî•
ques: Explain **counterflow vs parallel flow** heat exchangers.

answer.content:
**Parallel Flow:**
- Fluids enter same end, flow same direction
- Temperature difference decreases along length
- Lower efficiency

**Counterflow:**
- Fluids enter opposite ends, flow opposite directions
- More uniform temperature difference
- Higher efficiency
- Can achieve higher outlet temperature

**LMTD (Log Mean Temperature Difference):**
$$Q = UA √ó LMTD$$
$$LMTD = \frac{ŒîT_1 - ŒîT_2}{\ln(ŒîT_1/ŒîT_2)}$$

explanation: Counterflow preferred when possible. Shell-and-tube exchangers common in industry.

title: Process Flow Diagrams üìä
ques: What is the difference between **PFD** and **P&ID**?

answer.content:
**PFD (Process Flow Diagram):**
- Overview of process
- Major equipment
- Main process streams
- Operating conditions (T, P, flow)
- Material balance info

**P&ID (Piping & Instrumentation Diagram):**
- Detailed engineering drawing
- All piping, valves, fittings
- Instrumentation and controls
- Equipment tags and details
- Used for construction

**Symbols:** ISO 10628, ISA standards

explanation: PFD for understanding process; P&ID for building and operating it.

title: Reactor Design üî¨
ques: Compare **batch, CSTR, and PFR** reactor types.

answer.content:
| Reactor | Description | Use |
|---------|-------------|-----|
| **Batch** | Closed vessel, no flow during reaction | Small scale, specialty chemicals |
| **CSTR** | Continuous stirred, uniform composition | Large scale, liquid phase |
| **PFR** | Tubular, plug flow, no mixing | Gas phase, fast reactions |

**Key Differences:**
- CSTR: Operates at exit conditions
- PFR: Concentration varies along length
- For same conversion, PFR smaller for most kinetics

explanation: Real reactors may combine features. Design equations differ‚Äîintegrate for PFR, algebraic for CSTR.

title: Unit Operations üè≠
ques: List and describe common **unit operations** in chemical engineering.

answer.content:
**Unit Operations:**

| Category | Operations |
|----------|------------|
| **Heat Transfer** | Heat exchangers, evaporators |
| **Mass Transfer** | Distillation, absorption, extraction |
| **Fluid Flow** | Pumps, compressors, piping |
| **Mechanical** | Filtration, centrifugation, mixing |
| **Reaction** | Reactors (batch, continuous) |
| **Drying** | Spray, drum, freeze drying |

explanation: Unit operations combine to form complete processes. Scale-up from lab to plant is major challenge.

title: Process Control üéõÔ∏è
ques: Describe the components of a **process control loop**.

answer.content:
**Control Loop Components:**

| Component | Function | Example |
|-----------|----------|--------|
| **Sensor** | Measures process variable | Thermocouple |
| **Transmitter** | Converts to standard signal | 4-20 mA |
| **Controller** | Compares to setpoint, calculates action | PLC, DCS |
| **Final element** | Adjusts process | Control valve |

**Example:** Temperature control
- Sensor measures temperature
- Controller compares to setpoint
- Opens/closes steam valve

explanation: PID control most common. Advanced process control uses model-based methods.

title: Safety Systems ‚ö†Ô∏è
ques: What is **HAZOP** and how is it used in chemical plant safety?

answer.content:
**HAZOP (Hazard and Operability Study):**
Systematic review to identify hazards

**Process:**
1. Divide plant into nodes
2. Apply guide words to process parameters
3. Identify deviations and consequences
4. Recommend safeguards

**Guide Words:**
| Word | Meaning |
|------|--------|
| No/Not | Complete negation |
| More/Less | Quantitative change |
| Reverse | Opposite direction |
| Part of | Component missing |
| As well as | Additional material |

explanation: Chemical plants use layers of protection: BPCS, SIS, relief devices, containment. Process safety critical.

title: Scale-Up Challenges üìà
ques: What challenges arise when **scaling up** from laboratory to industrial production?

answer.content:
**Scale-Up Challenges:**

| Aspect | Issue |
|--------|-------|
| **Heat transfer** | Surface/volume ratio decreases |
| **Mixing** | Non-uniform, dead zones |
| **Mass transfer** | Concentration gradients |
| **Reaction time** | May change with scale |
| **Equipment** | Geometry can't be exactly scaled |

**Solutions:**
- Pilot plant testing
- Dimensional analysis
- CFD modeling
- Gradual scale-up (10√ó, 100√ó, ...)

explanation: Rule of thumb: Lab ‚Üí Pilot (10-100√ó) ‚Üí Demo ‚Üí Full scale. Each step validates assumptions.
